metadata.title: Palladium supported ionic liquid phase catalyst (Pd@SILP-PS) for room temperature Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction

Research Paper Palladium supported ionic liquid phase catalyst (Pd@SILP-PS) for room temperature Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction Sagar More a Sanjay Jadhav c Rajashri Salunkhe b Arjun Kumbhar a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, P.D.V.P. College, Tasgaon, Sangli, Maharashtra, India Department of Chemistry P.D.V.P. College Tasgaon Sangli Maharashtra India b Department of Chemistry, Shivaji University, Kolhapur, Maharashtra, India Department of Chemistry Shivaji University Kolhapur Maharashtra India c CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Pune, Maharashtra, India CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Pune Maharashtra India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A new Pd-SILP based on amino functionalized imidazolium ionic liquid immobilized on Merrifield resin (Pd@SILP-PS) has been synthesized. The catalyst was characterized by different techniques like FT-IR, SEM-EDS, TEM, TGA-DTA and XPS. The catalyst has shown to be highly active in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction of various aryl halides and aryl boronic acids in ethanol at room temperature. The activity of catalyst and the nature of product were highly dependent on the type of the solvent used, as well as the substituents present on the aryl halides. The protic polar solvent ethanol gave desired cross-coupling product in good to excellent yields at room temperature. However the aprotic polar solvent THF gave homocoupling product. The catalyst showed at least five times recyclability without a decrease in product yield. Keyword Palladium Ionic liquid SILP Immobilization Suzuki-Miyaura reaction 1 Introduction The past few decades have seen rapid development in the area of Pd catalyzed cross-coupling reactions [1,2]. Especially Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction [3,4] has been studied more widely owing to the importance of this reaction in the synthesis of many natural products, pharmaceutical intermediates and organic-polymers [5]. As compared to analogous cross-coupling reactions, the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction can be carried out under mild reaction conditions. This reaction has been widely catalyzed by homogeneous catalysts as these catalysts are highly active [6]. However, the high price of Pd metal and its possible contamination in the final product still overwhelm its use in large-scale applications. To avoid these problems, air-stable, recyclable heterogeneous catalysts based on suitable solid supports like carbon, biopolymer, silica, zeolites, organic polymers have been developed [7–11]. In recent years, ionic liquids (ILs) have been engrossed considerable interest in transition metal catalysis as a green, non-volatile, recoverable and recyclable reaction media for biphasic reactions, because of the ease of product and catalyst separation [12,13]. There are many reports cited in literature in which IL itself acts as a ligand in the form of ‘N-Heterocyclic Carbene’ (NHC) complexes [14]. Nevertheless, due to the substantial amount of ILs are required for biphasic separation and its high preparation cost, many of these ILs are used in very small amounts, in the form of ‘Supported Ionic Liquid Phase’ (SILP).. Though the ‘Supported Liquid Phase Catalysts (SLPC)’ have been reported previously [15], in recent years there is an upsurge in the application of SILP catalysts in many catalytic reactions [16,17]. The concept of SILP involves a formation of thin films of ILs containing metal catalysts, on the surface of a suitable solid support. This system leads to a significant decrease in the amount of IL as well as it increases the contact area between the two phases that enhances efficiency of the catalysts. The SILP concept also allows ease of catalyst separation and recycling. This ability of SILP catalysts can permit its potential use mainly in fixed-bed reactors [18]. In recent years only few numbers of Pd-SILP catalysts based on organic polymers and silica have been reported for various cross-coupling reactions [19–26]. While only one report mentioned by Gruttadauria et al. [27] for Pd supported on multi-layered, covalently supported ionic liquid phase (mlc-SILP) catalyst for the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction in aqueous medium. Recently we reported applications of amine functionalized ligands [28] supported on silica [29] as well as alumina-cellulose composite [30] for phosphine-free Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. In this link, we proposed to design highly efficient Pd supported on amine functioned SILP based on Merrifield resin. The conceptual picture of catalyst is represented in Fig. 1 . We speculated that the use of weakly binding amine would permit the facile ligand exchange and allows a much wider scope of σ-donation. Based on the precedent for using a SILP in the organic synthesis [31], we selected Pd@SILP-PS for the fast Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction in ethanol at room temperature. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Preparation of Pd@SILP-PS catalyst The procedure for preparing the Pd@SILP-PS catalyst is based on the modified method as described by Lee et al. [32] and schematically described in Scheme 1 . Initially, our synthesis began from the reaction of imidazole with Merrifield resin (4mmolg−1) to form imidazole functionalized resin (Imd-PS, 3.6mmolg−1). In a succeeding step, we geared up to support ethyllamine functioned imidazolium IL (IL-PS) on polymer by treating bromoethylamine·HBr with Imd-PS in the presence of K2CO3 in THF. The resulting IL-PS on treatment with Pd(OAc)2 at room temperature in ethanol gave Pd@SILP-PS catalyst. The content of anchored Pd on SILP was found to be 0.072mmolg−1 as determined by ICP-AES analysis. 2.2 Characterization of Pd@SILP-PS catalyst The prepared catalyst was then characterized by different characterization techniques like FT-IR, SEM-EDS, TEM, TG-DTA, and XPS. FT–IR analysis of materials is rather inconclusive, mainly due to relatively minor changes that reflect the lower amounts of the anchored ionic functionalities. However, in comparison with pure PS, FT-IR of Pd@SILP-PS gives a signal of quaternary imidazolium at 1101cm−1. The doublet at 3118 and 3228cm−1 indicate the presence of primary amine (NH2). SEM micrographs (Fig. 2 ) of (a) PS, (b) Imd-PS and (c) Pd@SILP-PS clearly reveal morphological changes in three materials. The uneven surface of the carrier beads of Imd-PS clearly indicates the modification in PS. As observed in the SEM image of Pd@SILP-PS, the immobilization of IL as well as Pd in the PS creates stress, which causes the breakdown of PS beads [33]. The deposition of palladium on Pd@SILP-PS catalyst was confirmed by detecting Pd species on polymer beads using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) that was taken at random points on the surface (Fig. 3 ). Attempts to directly observe the PdNPs on SILP were done by using TEM analysis, which is shown in Fig. 4 . The catalyst consists of narrowly dispersed microspheres of about 1μm in diameter. As the thickness of the polymer sphere does not leave a clear observation of PdNPs. But at the edges a few extremely small PdNPs are visible. Most of PdNPs distributed homogeneously with the diameters bellow 10nm. The XPS data of Pd@SILP-PS catalyst (Fig. 5 ) shows two peaks at binding energy 340.44eV and 335.80eV for electron transitions of Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, which clearly indicate that Pd is present in Pd (0) state. TGA analysis was carried out to investigate the thermal behavior of catalysts. TGA profile of Pd@SILP-PS shows that the catalyst is stable up to 345°C (Fig. 6 ). The high weight loss in two steps of around 84% at a temperature between 300 and 600°C was due to the oxidative decomposition of the IL and polymeric material. 2.3 Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction by Pd@SILP-PS catalyst The catalytic activity of the prepared Pd@SILP-PS catalyst was evaluated for the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction at room temperature. At the beginning, to evaluate the influence of base and solvent, we selected 4-bromobenzophenone and phenylboronic acid as a model reaction companions (Scheme 2 ). The reaction was initially performed using 1mol% catalyst and 2mmolK2CO3 as a base in ethanol. A very good conversion was obtained in 10min at room temperature (Table 1 , entry 1). It was apparent that carbonate base was more effective in activating the substrates as compared to the K3PO4 (Table 1 , entry 2 and 3). Though, NaOAc work best in terms of reaction yield, the reaction was slightly sluggish (Table 1 , entry 4). We then studied the effect of the amount of base by performing the model reaction with decreasing amount of K2CO3. When the reaction was carried out under base-free conditions no product was formed (Table 1 , entry 5). The use of 1mmolK2CO3 work best indicating that the base is not needed for activation of phenylboronic acid, but its role is to neutralize the boric acid [34] as one equivalent base showed good conversion (95% yield) in 10min (Table 1 , entry 6). Next, the influence of nature, of solvent on catalytic activity was studied for model reaction, and it was observed that solvent play a very important role in determining the activity of the catalyst as well as the nature of the product. When the reaction was carried out in THF at room temperature, the only homocoupling product was observed product (Table 2 , entry 1). In toluene, no reaction was taking place at room temperature, but at 70°C temperature extensive homocoupling occurred (Table 2, entry 2), similarly DMF also gave the homocoupling product (Table 2, entry 3). No reaction was observed in acetonitrile at room temperature at a prolonged reaction time (Table 2 , entry 4). Unfortunately water is totally failed to convert reactants into a desired coupling product (Table 2, entry 5) even at elevated temperature. Thus, only ethanol was found to be best solvent for getting the desired product (Table 2 , entry 6). Thus the use of ethanol renders this protocol quite useful and amenable as it is easily available, cheap and environmental friendly. To show the applicability of catalyst for the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction, various aryl iodides, and bromides were reacted with different arylboronic acids under optimized reaction condition, and the consequences are demonstrated in Chart 1 . It was noted that the activity of Pd@SILP-PS was highly dependent on the nature of the group present on aryl halides as well arylboronic acids. Though the catalyst showed excellent activity for coupling aryl iodides with aryl boronic acids, aryl bromides were also found to be the best substrates giving good coupling yields. It is clear that the cross-coupling is efficient over a wide range of ortho- meta- and para-substituted aryl halides as well as variations in the electronic nature of the substituents. The catalysts also allowed smooth coupling of bromo- and iodo-anisole which are generally less active under room temperature. Again steric hindrance of aryl halides is not a major factor for the formation of biphenyls, as the cross-coupling reaction of ortho-substituted aryl halides are smoothly converted into a desired product in good-excellent yields. The coupling of heteroaryl bromides also occurs efficiently with moderate yield. For practical applications of heterogeneous catalysts, the lifetime of the catalyst and its level of reusability are very important for the industrial point of view. Hence, recyclability test of the catalyst was examined in the case of the model reaction under optimized reaction condition. After first use, the catalyst was recovered by simple filtration and extensively washed with aqueous ethanol, dichloromethane, and acetone. The catalyst was dried under vacuum and reused for the next reaction cycle and the consequences are described in Fig. 7 . It was noted that the yield of the product decreased slightly in the subsequent uses (95–91%) indicating that the catalyst remain in SILP. The TEM image of recycled catalyst showed that very slight agglomeration of Pd was observed (Fig. 4), indicating that SILP decreases the aggregation of PdNPs. 3 Conclusion In summary, we have described a synthesis of new Pd-SILP based on amino functionalized imidazolium ionic liquid based on Merrifield resin. This SILP catalyst was acting as an efficient, stable and recyclable catalyst for the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions involving various aryl halides and aryl boronic acids in ethanol at room temperature. The activity of the catalyst and the nature of the product were extremely dependent on the nature of the solvent used as well as the substituents present on the aryl halides. The prepared catalyst showed good recyclability, over five catalytic cycles with a slight decrease in product yield and no substantial Pd aggregation occurred. coredata.dc:description: A new Pd-SILP based on amino functionalized imidazolium ionic liquid immobilized on Merrifield resin (Pd@SILP-PS) has been synthesized. The catalyst was characterized by different techniques like FT-IR, SEM-EDS, TEM, TGA-DTA and XPS. The catalyst has shown to be highly active in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction of various aryl halides and aryl boronic acids in ethanol at room temperature. The activity of catalyst and the nature of product were highly dependent on the type of the solvent used, as well as the substituents present on the aryl halides. The protic polar solvent ethanol gave desired cross-coupling product in good to excellent yields at room temperature. However the aprotic polar solvent THF gave homocoupling product. The catalyst showed at least five times recyclability without a decrease in product yield.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium supported ionic liquid phase catalyst (Pd@SILP-PS) for room temperature Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction
